title: Create your weights profile
text: risk.assessr package default weighting profile assigns weighting profile 1 riskmetric giving equal weighting risk metric. wish create weighting profile, 1 - go R script create_weights_profile() R folder. 2 - Open script see following code: 3 - set weights risk metric 4 - save file 5 - Go Build Tab 6 - Click Tab 7 - Click Document, Clean Install, Load 8 - Run riskmetric functions assess_pkg() assess_pkg_r_package() calculate riskmetrics using weights profile.
code: ``` r library(risk.assessr)  create_weights_profile <- function() {   weights <- c(     has_bug_reports_url = .2,     license = .1,     has_examples = .4,     has_maintainer = .2,     has_news = .2,     size_codebase = .2,     has_source_control = .1,     has_vignettes = .4,     has_website = .4,     news_current = .2,     export_help = .2,     export_calc = .2,     check = .75,     covr = .6,     dep_score = .5,     revdep_score = .1   )   return(weights) }

title: Authors and Citation
text: Edward Gillian. Maintainer, author. Hugo Bottois. Author. Paulin Charliquart. Author. Andre Couturier. Author. Sanofi. Copyright holder, funder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Gillian E, Bottois H, Charliquart P, Couturier (2025). risk.assessr: Assessing package risk metrics. R package version 2.0.0, https://sanofi-public.github.io/risk.assessr/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {risk.assessr: Assessing package risk metrics},   author = {Edward Gillian and Hugo Bottois and Paulin Charliquart and Andre Couturier},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 2.0.0},   url = {https://sanofi-public.github.io/risk.assessr/}, }

title: Assessing package risk metrics
text: risk.assessr helps initial determining package’s reliability security terms maintenance, documentation, dependencies. package designed carry risk assessment R packages beginning validation process (either internal open source). calculates risk metrics : Core metrics - includes R command check, unit test coverage composite coverage dependencies Documentation metrics - availability vignettes, news tracking, example(s), return object description exported functions, type license Dependency Metrics - package dependencies reverse dependencies also calculates : Traceability matrix - matching function / test descriptions tests match test pass/fail

title: Assessing package risk metrics
text: package executes following tasks: upload source package(tar.gz file) Unpack tar.gz file Install package locally Run code coverage Run traceability matrix Run R CMD check Run risk assessment metrics using default user defined weighting

title: Assessing package risk metrics
text: package fixes number errors pharmaR/riskmetric running R CMD check code coverage locally installed packages user defined weighting works Suggests added checking dependencies assess_dependencies assess_reverse_dependencies sigmoid point increased assess_dependencies value range changed fit scoring metrics

title: Assessing package risk metrics
text: Create Personal Access Token (PAT) github Log github account (forget add SSH Sanofi-Public authorization) Create .Renviron file GITHUBTOKEN : restart R session can install package :

title: Assessing package risk metrics
text: assess package, following steps: 1 - save package tar.gz file can done RStudio -> Build Tab -> -> Build Source Package 2 - Run following code sample loading add path parameter tar.gz package source code
code: # for local tar.gz R package risk_assess_package <- risk_assess_pkg()  risk_assess_package <- risk_assess_pkg(path/to/your/package)

title: Assessing package risk metrics
text: function processes renv.lock produce risk metric data package. Note: process can time-consuming recommended performed batch job within GitHub Action.
code: # for local renv.lock file  risk_assess_package <- risk_assess_pkg(path/to/your/package)

title: Assess package — assess_pkg

title: Assess package — assess_pkg
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # set CRAN repo to enable running of reverse dependencies r = getOption("repos") r["CRAN"] = "http://cran.us.r-project.org" options(repos = r)  pkg_source_path <- file.choose() pkg_name <- sub("\\.tar\\.gz$", "", basename(pkg_source_path))  modified_tar_file <- modify_description_file(pkg_source_path)  # Set up the package using the temporary file install_list <- set_up_pkg(modified_tar_file)  # Extract information from the installation list build_vignettes <- install_list$build_vignettes package_installed <- install_list$package_installed pkg_source_path <- install_list$pkg_source_path rcmdcheck_args <- install_list$rcmdcheck_args  # check if the package needs to be installed locally package_installed <- install_package_local(pkg_source_path)  # Check if the package was installed successfully if (package_installed == TRUE) {   # Assess the package   assess_package <- assess_pkg(pkg_source_path, rcmdcheck_args)   # Output the assessment result } else {   message("Package installation failed.") } } # }

title: Modify the DESCRIPTION File in a R Package Tarball — modify_description_file
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   modified_tar <- modify_description_file("path/to/mypackage.tar.gz")   print(modified_tar)   # Unpack the tar.gz file   contents <- unpack_tarball(modified_tar)   description_path <- file.path(contents, "DESCRIPTION")   description_content <- readLines(description_path)   cat(description_content, sep = "\n") } # }

text: pkg_source_path directory path R project rcmdcheck_args list arguments pass `rcmdcheck::rcmdcheck`

title: Run R CMD CHECK — run_rcmdcheck
text: rcmdcheck takes either tarball installation directory. basename `pkg_source_path` package name version pasted together returned score calculated via weighted sum notes (0.10), warnings (0.25), errors (1.0). maximum score 1 (indicating errors, notes warnings) minimum score 0 (equal 1 error, 4 warnings, 10 notes). scoring methodology taken directly [riskmetric::metric_score.pkg_metric_r_cmd_check()].

what: Score a package for dependencies — score_dependencies
title: Score a package for dependencies — score_dependencies
text: Calculates regularized score based number dependencies package . Convert number dependencies NROW(x) validation score [0,1] $$ 1 / (1 + exp(-0.5 * (NROW(x) + 19))) $$

title: Score a package for dependencies — score_dependencies
Score a package for dependencies — score_dependencies
text: x number dependencies

title: Score a package for dependencies — score_dependencies
text: numeric value 0 (low number  dependencies)   1 (high number dependencies)

title: Score a package for dependencies — score_dependencies
text: removed - 1 formula e.g. $$ 1 - 1 / (1 + exp(NROW(x)- 19)) $$ reverse return value e.g. 0 - low; 1 - high scoring function classic logistic curve $$ / (1 + exp(-k(x-x[0])) $$ \(x = NROW(x)\), sigmoid midpoint 20 reverse dependencies, ie. \(x[0] = 19\), logistic growth rate \(k = 0.5\). $$ 1 / (1 + exp(NROW(x)- 19)) $$

what: Scoring method for number of reverse dependencies a package has — score_reverse_dependencies
title: Scoring method for number of reverse dependencies a package has — score_reverse_dependencies
text: Score package number reverse dependencies ; regularized Convert number reverse dependencies length(x) validation score [0,1] $$ 1 / (1 + exp(-0.5 * (sqrt(length(x)) + sqrt(20)))) $$

title: Scoring method for number of reverse dependencies a package has — score_reverse_dependencies
Scoring method for number of reverse dependencies a package has — score_reverse_dependencies
text: x number dependencies

title: Scoring method for number of reverse dependencies a package has — score_reverse_dependencies
text: numeric value 1 (high number reverse dependencies)   0 (low number reverse dependencies)

title: Scoring method for number of reverse dependencies a package has — score_reverse_dependencies
text: scoring function classic logistic curve $$ 1 / (1 + exp(-k(x-x[0])) $$ square root scale number reverse dependencies \(x = sqrt(length(x))\), sigmoid midpoint 20 reverse dependencies, ie. \(x[0] = sqrt(15)\), logistic growth rate \(k = 0.5\). $$ 1 / (1 + -0.5 * exp(sqrt(length(x)) - sqrt(20))) $$

title: risk.assessr 2.0.0
text: Author Metadata Expansion: Added $author section including maintainer, funder, full list contributing authors ORCID IDs roles. Hosting Metadata Extraction: New $host section includes GitHub CRAN, Bioconductor internal package GitHub Repository: created_at stars forks recent_commits_count CRAN download: total_download last_month_download Package version: available_version last_version Bioconductor compatibility: assess_pkg_r_package() function now fetches bioconductor source package renv.lock processing: risk_assess_pkg_lock_files() function now processes renv.lock pak.lock files Suggested Dependency Analysis: Introduced $suggested_deps output tibble source, suggested_function, targeted_package, contextual message. Traceability Matrix: now processes reports regular, S3, S4 functions. Package validation report: HTML report creation interactive features package validation

title: risk.assessr 2.0.0
text: Structured Dependency Extraction: Dependencies now returned structured nested lists $dependencies$imports $dependencies$suggests, replacing previous flat string format. suggested package now includes installed version getsession() Added $license_name readable license detection, e.g., "MIT + file LICENSE" Added $rev_deps returning list reverse dependency risk_assess_pkg() now includes optional parameter “path” locally stored package remove httr2 tibble dependencies

title: risk.assessr 1.0.0
text: First package version inspired riskmetric. Package features include: Run CMD, test coverage Traceability Matrix Metadata (Date, system, OS) Quality extraction metrics (documentation, license, examples, vignettes) assess_pkg_r_package() function fetches source code CRAN
